—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. We on this side of the House wish that you had been occupying the chair last evening when we tried to raise a couple of other matters because clearly your interpretation, and the way in which you would see legislation coming before this committee and the main chamber, is an important element in us being able to raise issues in this parliament.

BREAK.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, these particular bills, the Excise Tariff (Fuel Rates Amendments) Bill 1997 , the Customs Tariff (Fuel Rates Amendments) Bill 1997 , the Fuel Misuse (Penalty Surcharge) Bill 1997 , the Fuel Sale (Penalty Surcharge) Bill 1997 , the Fuel Blending (Penalty Surcharge) Bill 1997 , and the Fuel (Penalty Surcharges) Administration Bill 1997 ‐ and not to forget the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 , the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 are all concerned about the same issue. They are concerned about redressing a revenue problem for this government. They are concerned about the situation where people in some way rort the system as it applies to fuel substitution. It is concerned that there are penalties imposed on people and that when they are caught there is redress.

It is hoped that in all circumstances—whether it be abuse in fuel substitution; the need for further legislation arising out of the customs area; rorts perpetrated through the Australian Taxation Office; people trying to rip off the system in a more generic way by failing to properly adhere to standards, to proper concerns that are raised more broadly in the community—when those sorts of cases are discovered and people understand that they happen and the redress that will come through legislation like this is applied, those people are penalised. They must be penalised not only through the legislation, such as the penalty surcharge bill when we are talking about fuel, but it must be the case more generally, if they are caught and those penalties are applied, that there is no cover‐up by anyone and that that matter is thoroughly investigated.

Once again I indicate to the Main Committee that the opposition does not oppose the fuel legislation package. We do not oppose the customs bills that are relevant to this matter. We will not oppose the government amendments that have been drafted to pick up and correct some technical aspects of the legislation. We are very grateful that the government has allowed this legislation to be debated in this place.

We hope that the same concern that this government has for ensuring that—where there are problems with rorts in the system, such as in fuel substitution and in the imposition of penalties—if legislation of this nature can be debated here, any opportunity where clearly there is a hint—in fact probably more than a hint—of impropriety taking place, whether it be at the highest levels of government or elsewhere, the opportunities of this parliament are not thwarted in an honest attempt by an opposition to raise them in an appropriate way.
The comments made a little earlier on by my colleague the member for Fisher should be dwelt on by all members of this place. I thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to address this rather complex set of bills brought about in part by the decision of the High Court in Ha and Lim and also the Walter Hammond case in New South Wales. Both of those cases took away the ability of states to impose franchise fees on various items which raised a substantial amount of revenue for the states, and subsequently that revenue had to be urgently replaced by the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: A series of bills went through this House on 28 August. They were introduced into this House on that date but they were to operate with effect from 5 August in order to deal with that crisis that arose in terms of state and Commonwealth funding. Prior to the introduction of those bills—in fact on 25 June—the Excise Tariff (Fuel Rates Amendments) Bill 1997 , the Customs Tariff (Fuel Rates Amendments) Bill 1997 , the Fuel Misuse (Penalty Surcharge) Bill 1997 , the Fuel Sale (Penalty Surcharge) Bill 1997 , the Fuel Blending (Penalty Surcharge) Bill 1997 , the Fuel Blending (Penalty Surcharge) Bill 1997 , the Fuel (Penalty Surcharges) Administration Bill 1997 and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 had been introduced into this House to make provision for an additive to be placed in fuels which were sold for non‐transport uses and attracted an excise of 7.2c per litre.

You can see the obvious advantage in bringing fuels of that kind into the country, paying 7.2c per litre, blending them later and selling them on as fuels intended for on‐road use for which the excise duty is 34.697c per litre. It is very difficult to distinguish those fuels—things like kerosene have other uses—and they can be easily mixed up and put into uses for which excise has not been paid. That makes the prosecution of anyone avoiding tax extremely difficult. In fact, the department estimated that $25 million a year was lost in uncollected excise duties through people paying duty of 7c per litre rather than 34c per litre.

It is an area that is very difficult to prosecute, whereas a dye or a colourless marker, which is already successful is some European countries, can be added to fuel. This makes the prosecution of people found using, selling or illegally blending fuels for on‐road use that much easier in the courts; the standard of proof required then is easy to jump over. Exactly what that dye or blend is going to be is, as yet, undecided. It has been left to the Institute of Petroleum, state revenue offices and motoring consumer organisations to come up with what the additives will be.

It is a very interesting concept in terms of the amount of money estimated as being lost. Some estimates since then have been twice that amount. However, the implementation costs have been estimated at something like $5.97 million over four years, with additional running costs of $1.54 million after that. A cost‐risk analysis has been done. It seems that the government's estimate of 0.004c per litre is being disputed by the industry, which reckons that the cost will be 0.15c per litre. No doubt this will be passed on to users so we may see a slight rise in off‐road fuel costs due to the requirement for an additive. However, given that most petrol companies only allow fuel stations to make a cent a litre anyway, in this instance it may well serve the industry to absorb that cost itself because there is quite a head of steam building up with operators and franchisees of petrol stations about their profitability and their ability to trade in today's fuel distribution environment.

BREAK.PARA: It is an issue that has arisen recently in my electorate and it is of great concern. We constantly require our distributors and station operators to apply these laws. Often it seems that the consumers, or the operators themselves, pay the price. That is a concern that I will raise on behalf of the station operators in my electorate.

The other issue involved in the 34c per litre charge for on‐road fuel consumption is that it is a disincentive for people to use their cars. I applaud that. I would like to see more people taking advantage of public transport. I live in outer western Sydney. We have a very serious air pollution problem, which the city car users can only address by not using their cars in such an avid fashion, probably by car pooling—

TALK.START.PARA: —In an environmentally friendly way.
—In an environmentally friendly way.

BREAK.PARA: Recently, I noticed in one article that some time in the next millennium Mercedes is looking at introducing a new car the size of a Barina. It would retail at around $40,000, and apparently run on hydrogen with no emissions. So, again, with new technology catching up with us, we will no doubt see another rash of bills coming through. I hope that there is an encouragement to use this type of technology, rather than continuing with the fuel emissions that we currently have resulting in the terrible problems we have in Sydney, especially, with car and truck petrol and diesel emission pollution.

We ended up having to have the remaining two bills, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997, introduced to go through with this package to overcome the situation where these bills, which were introduced on 25 June, introducing new excise levels, would not then negate what actually occurred in the August set of bills which addressed that High Court decision where the funds wilted away. So, to avoid the set of bills reducing the actual excise levels which were set down in that previous legislation, these two amendment bills have to be passed concurrently so that in fact the excise levels stay where they are and revenue levels are maintained.

So it has been a rather interesting package of bills. It has some minor drafting inconsistencies which are being fixed up in the latter bills, and a number of technical amendments to the schedule, but they basically do not alter the financial impact of the entire package of bills that was passed in August, and which we are discussing today.

I notice that it does not have any dissent from the opposition. They had discussed this addition of additives as early as 1993 when they passed some earlier legislation to make it easier for the Australian Customs Service to determine when people were not complying. It has been a difficult legal problem to solve with the standards of proof that Australia requires before someone is convicted.

In Australia we do not, as a rule, convict people out of hand on aspersion without actually giving them the opportunity to give their side of the story, or to put the facts as known to them before a properly appointed judicial court for consideration. An incredibly high standard of proof is required before we proclaim to the world that people are guilty of any misdemeanour beyond reasonable doubt. These fuel additives will make sure that that standard of proof is able to be met by the Customs authorities.

Relative to a few comments made earlier in this chamber, I think that it does well for the opposition to bear in mind those standards of proof and our Australian judicial system and standards of behaviour, even in parliament where we are covered by parliamentary privilege, and to extend to people the courtesy of at least a trial before they are convicted beyond reasonable doubt in the media or in parliament. Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis, Ralph, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill that is before the House is non‐controversial in the sense that it is supported by the opposition. And, of course, it is an appropriate bill to support because it is stopping a rort costing revenue some estimated $25 million a year through illegal blending and substitution of petroleum products. It is highly appropriate that the government moves to take action in an effective way against such bleeding of the tax revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: I also note that in the budget the government has also provided additional resources to the Customs Service to enable it to monitor the scheme, to investigate where fuel substitution is suspected and to take necessary action against offenders. That is very much supported by the opposition in order to make sure that the scheme is effective.

It is important to protect the revenue in this area because this is a major revenue earner. This is an area where the government raises some $10¾billion a year, in gross terms. That is the total revenue for fuel tax. If one takes account of the diesel fuel rebate of that tax revenue, then the net revenue raised is some $9.3 billion. It represents over eight per cent of total tax revenue raised and it is a very important element of the total revenue raising by the Commonwealth.

It is therefore interesting, in that context, that we have calls for the abolition of fuel tax coming from within the government. That is a serious issue indeed, particularly given where it is coming from—not from just a backbencher, but from a member of the ministry. In fact, it is the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) who has been calling for the abolition of fuel tax in the context of tax reform—a euphemism for the introduction of a goods and services tax. In that context, he is saying that what must be done is to pursue the same attitude towards fuel tax as was in the Fightback package of 1993, which involved the abolition of fuel tax and the imposition of a goods and services tax on fuel but nothing else.
To prove that, I note that in the Australian of 16 June an article headed `Fischer fails to rule out tax increase' says:
He—
that is, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer—
presented strong support for a goods and services tax, as well as reaffirming his support for scrapping petrol excise.
Later on, the article quotes him from the Seven Network's Face to Face program when he said:
"But, above all else, we want to see those transport fuel taxes taken out of the system and, in fact, replaced by a rebatable form of value‐added tax, goods and services tax."
Similar quotes were also contained in the Financial Review about a month later, where he repeated the call.

So in this important area of fuel tax, where we are trying to protect the revenue in this legislation, what we have is the Deputy Prime Minister calling for the abolition of this total means of raising tax. This needs some examination, because we do have a low level of overall fuel tax in Australia at the present time and, therefore, low fuel prices. The International Energy Agency, which is a body to which Australia belongs and whose members are essentially most of the members of the OECD, did a review in 1997 of Australia's energy policies. In that report it said:
Due to lower consumption taxes than in other IEA countries, post tax retail prices on automotive fuels in Australia are generally lower than those in other IEA countries.

What it is saying is that we have low consumption taxes on fuel and, therefore, we have low overall fuel prices. It goes on to give examples: Japan is more than double us; the UK is much higher; New Zealand is a little higher; and Canada and the USA are lower—but they are the lowest in the developed world by a long way.

In a context where Australia already has relatively low automotive fuel taxes and, therefore, relatively low automotive fuel prices, we have the Deputy Prime Minister of this country and his party advocating making our fuel taxes and prices much lower. How much lower would they go? This point has been analysed by an authoritative source. It is the Department of Transport and Regional Development. In a discussion paper entitled `Implications of a goods and services tax on Commonwealth road funding arrangements' the department said:
Currently fuel excise rates are 34.6 cents per litre (cpl) on diesel and unleaded petrol and 36.7 cpl leaded petrol. Under a 15% GST—
which was the rate in Fightback—
the effective tax rate would reduce to around 3.2 cpl‐
as against 34.6 for unleaded petrol—
to over 8 cpl . . . depending on State and location.

So you are reduced to around 3.2c per litre in the capital cities and up to eight per cent in other areas, depending on the retail price. We can see that this involves a drastic reduction, an enormous reduction, in taxes on fuel. On the department's figures it would mean a cut of at least 31.4 cents per litre for diesel and unleaded petrol in capital cities. This in turn would mean much lower fuel prices. In this regard, the department said:

Australian motorists already pay less for their fuel than most other developed countries, significantly so in many cases. Only in the USA . . . and Canada is fuel cheaper to buy. The abolition of the fuel excise, replaced by a GST only tax, would reduce the (current) Sydney price per litre from around 70 cents per litre to around 40 cents for private consumption use, or 35 cents for business users.

We are talking about, in broad terms, a reduction from 70c to 40c—an extraordinary reduction of over 40 per cent, which the Deputy Prime Minister, and presumably his party, are strongly advocating within the government, and doing publicly.

The calculation of reductions of that order assumes that the state franchise fees would remain. As we know, as a result of the High Court decision the Commonwealth is now faced with having to levy excise to make up for the fact that the franchise fees are apparently unconstitutional. So the figuring that has been done in the departmental article assumes—in fact it was written before the High Court decision—that the state franchise fees apply.

If, of course, the tax were taken through so that all of the excise currently being raised by the Commonwealth on behalf of the states was also abolished, the reduction in fuel prices would be even greater than the department is stating in its comments. It is interesting to see what the department concluded about this outcome. It said:
The abolition of the fuel excise would lead to Australia having the lowest tax on fuel of all developed countries.
I repeat: `of all developed countries'. It then went on:

BREAK.PARA: A reduction in fuel prices of this order would impact on Australia's credibility in the international arena. Australia is already under international criticism for not meeting its obligations under agreements covering greenhouse gas emissions.

And well might it say that, because it would make Australia an international pariah regarding the issue of greenhouse gas and climate warming, because we would clearly be taking action to increase considerably our emissions of greenhouse gases and not to reduce them.

What would be the effect on greenhouse gas emissions in Australia if this policy were to be pursued? There can be no doubt that such a policy would cause increased emissions of greenhouse gases in Australia. If car and truck fuel prices fall by over 40 per cent, who could doubt that there would be much higher use of automotive vehicles, with much higher greenhouse gas emissions coming from this source?

Australia already has a high level of greenhouse gas emission. We are about the 16th largest emitter of greenhouse gases in the world, even though we produce only around 1.5 per cent of all greenhouse gases. In per capita terms, we are very high. The International Energy Agency, in its 1997 Australia review, in regard to energy related carbon dioxide emissions, says that Australia was the eighth largest emitter in 1994, the second largest emitter per capita after the United States and the second largest emitter per unit of GDP after Greece. The IEA was talking about energy related carbon dioxide emissions. So it can be seen that in per capita terms we are a high emitter of greenhouse gases from the energy source and, indeed, overall.

Narrowing the energy sector down to the transport sector, the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics 1996 report on transport and greenhouse shows that, although transport is responsible for only 12 per cent of Australia's greenhouse gas emissions, on a per capita basis we are the third highest emitter of carbon dioxide, with only Canada and the United States, which have at present much lower fuel prices than ours, being higher than us on per capita carbon dioxide emissions. So Australia has emissions of 3.84 tonnes per capita. It was 16 per cent above the OECD average and over 4½ times the world average per capita. Although that would be partly attributable to distance factors in Australia, we nevertheless have a poor record on fuel efficient cars.

The International Energy Agency says that our average fuel consumption per passenger car of 8.9 litres per 100 kilometres is significantly higher than the IEA average and that we are the third highest after the United States and Canada. Australia is already at the very upper end of per capita greenhouse gas emissions from its transport sector. Certainly, the United States of America at 6.11 tonnes per capita and Canada at 5.46 tonnes per capita are way above us. But if, as the Deputy Prime Minister is proposing, we cut our fuel prices to near the levels that prevail in Canada and the United States, we can expect that our greenhouse gas emissions from the transport sector will rapidly accelerate towards the levels of these extravagant user countries through increased use of vehicles and reduced incentives to increase fuel efficiency of our cars.

What would be the effect of this on Australia's international standing if a policy such as that which the Deputy Prime Minister is advocating was to be followed through? I must say that at any time to be advocating a policy of this kind, which encourages wasteful use of a scarce non‐renewable resource, increases pollution and traffic congestion in our cities, and adds to greenhouse emissions and the global warming problem, would be utterly irresponsible. To be advocating it now in the current context of Australia already battling to get any support for its policy on greenhouse gas emission targets for the first decade of the next century is sheer madness.

As the third conference of the parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change—to be held in Kyoto in December of this year—draws near, Australia's policy of wanting differentiated greenhouse gas emission targets based on the concept of an equal degree of economic hurt to all in annex 1 countries—which are basically the OECD countries and eastern Europe—seems to have precious few, if any, supporters. Japan was said by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to be sympathetic, but it is now advocating a uniform reduction target, not a differentiated one.

The Prime Minister came back from the United States feeling chuffed about his reception on the greenhouse gas issue, but President Clinton and his advisers have since indicated support for a uniform target. President Clinton's key adviser on this issue said he did not understand the Australian argument. That is Mr Tim Worth, the US Undersecretary for Global Affairs. He said he just did not understand what Australia was talking about.

We saw last week at the South Pacific Forum in the Cook Islands how isolated Australia was: 15 to one was the generally accepted position. Even New Zealand was against us, and that is particularly significant because the modelling by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics on the economic impact of uniform reduction targets for greenhouse gas emissions shows that New Zealand is more adversely affected than Australia by the imposition of uniform targets. But are they adopting the same position as Australia? No, they are not. They are not giving us one ounce of support in the international argument on this issue. They are lined up with those who are calling for binding emission reduction targets.

Australia is in the position where it is the only industrialised country refusing to support binding emission reduction targets. We are saying we will sign up to some target, but it has to be an increase. Everyone else is saying they will sign up to a reduction target. We are one of only a few countries that are not supporting a uniform reduction.

Australia's international standing is increasingly being brought into question because of this issue. Just imagine what it will be like when the rest of the world learns that this government is contemplating a massive reduction in fuel taxes and prices and so encouraging greatly increased emission of greenhouse gases. Any chance of anyone listening to Australia's argument will be utterly and completely lost. We will be seen as utterly selfish and irresponsible and risk becoming a complete international pariah.

Even the Department of Transport and Regional Development pointed out what a problem it would be for us in relation to the international arena.Our credibility on this issue has been dealt a grievous blow, in addition to these statements, by our cuts to energy efficiency and energy research programs in this year's budget, which reduced funding to the national energy efficiency program by $11 million after a $3 million cut the previous year and wound up the Energy Research and Development Corporation to save $37 million.

This government is cutting funds in this crucial area of energy efficiency and development of energy alternatives by $50 million and then going to the rest of the world and saying, `Hey, we need a special case to cover us because we have got such a problem with greenhouse gases.' They might rightly say, `Well, what are you doing about it?' And we say, `We're cutting expenditure in this area.' Terrific! What a great argument! What a message it sends about our concern to reduce greenhouse gas emissions which, per capita, are amongst the highest in the world.

But as important as these cuts are, they are minor compared to the reaction that we could expect to a government policy to slash automotive fuel taxes and prices. To be advocating this now, in the lead‐up to Kyoto, invites scorn and derision from the rest of the world rather than the serious consideration of arguments that the government is trying to put to other countries. How can a country possibly look as though it is concerned about the overall issue of global warming and be taken seriously when it says that it just wants to be treated fairly when it is simultaneously considering action that would substantially increase its greenhouse gas emissions? To have any chance of being taken seriously, Australia has to be seen to be doing as much as it reasonably can to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions. Clearly, the Deputy Prime Minister's tax policy does not fit into that category.

If the Prime Minister wants to save Australia from international humiliation and scorn, he must repudiate his Deputy Prime Minister—and he must do it immediately. He must declare forthwith that Australia is not going to slash its fuel taxes and prices and, for good measure, he should also restore the budget cuts in the energy efficiency research area and seriously consider at least some of the other policies that would help to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, such as those which are set out in the International Energy Agency report on Australia—which I have not got time to go into.

He should also of course be looking very closely at the policy on land clearance, which, in Australia's case, accounts for an enormous percentage of our greenhouse gas emissions. Twenty‐three per cent of our greenhouse gas emissions come from land clearance—23 per cent as against 12 per cent from the transport sector—and most of this is occurring in Queensland. We are clearing—can you believe it?—660,000 hectares per annum. This is almost Amazonian in its rate of clearance, and most of that—450,000—is in Queensland. Most of it involves the clearance of broadacre native vegetation.

The government is boasting about its Natural Heritage Trust and its national vegetation initiative, but that will not be effective if we allow the continuance of this extraordinary rate of clearance, which is boosting our greenhouse gas emissions and making us look insincere and unconcerned about greenhouse gas emissions at the same time as we are trying to persuade the rest of the world as to how concerned we are about it and why we need special treatment. They would rightly say to us, `Get your own house in order first; then come back to us with arguments for special treatment,' particularly in the context where the Deputy Prime Minister is arguing for a policy which is irresponsible in the extreme on any front, and particularly in the context of our moving towards the Kyoto conference.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to this series of legislation today, I would firstly like to deal with some of the taxation reform issues associated with the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 . On 5 August, the High Court made a decision invalidating New South Wales tobacco business franchise fees. The decision also effectively struck off the states' and territories' abilities to collect fees and excise charges on tobacco, fuel and alcohol. I think that we all know the story, so I will not dwell on that too long.

The federal government initiated a rescue package or a safety net provision whereby the government would collect the state and territory charges on their behalf. The High Court decision was certainly a factor in re‐sparking the debate on the need for fundamental taxation reform in our country. It is an example of the growing, precarious and uncertain nature of the tax base in Australia.

I was interested in what the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) had to say in relation to the High Court decision, but unfortunately, I think he missed the point entirely. The ability of the states and territories to collect certain charges and excise has been seriously challenged. Indeed, the need for change and reform in the area of Commonwealth‐state financial relations is one of the criteria the government will be looking at very closely.

There are many differences between the coalition and Labor on the issue of taxation reform. On the one hand, we have the Liberal‐National coalition advocating a simpler and fairer tax system. On the other, we have the ALP advocating doing nothing about tax—living in the 1950s, keeping it complicated, unfair and inequitable.

BREAK.PARA: As the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) quite rightly observes, you could not believe what they say anyway. On the one hand, we have the Liberal‐National coalition advocating a lower personal income tax and lower payroll tax and, on the other, we have the ALP advocating higher income tax, higher payroll tax, higher sales tax and the old chestnut, to quote the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), death duties. On the one hand we have the Liberal‐National coalition advocating a modern and progressive tax system and on the other we have the ALP saying that they will not change anything: `When the system breaks down, we will just keep on patching it up again and again.' That is what they are saying.

The coalition wants to put an end to the patch and fill approach to taxation reform in Australia. But in the meantime, we have some problems to deal with. As one of the memoranda to these series of bills explains, while the Commonwealth safety net measures maintain the budget integrity of the states and territories, there are still some holes to plug. The Excise Tariff (Fuel Rates Amendments) Bill 1997 revises many of the descriptions of fuel presently contained in the act to prominently relate those descriptions to fuel containing a chemical marker. The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 amends the revised rates incorporating the safety net into the new chemical marker orientated descriptions.

But, predominantly, these bills deal with the government's desire to crack down on fuel substitution. It is important to cut down on the misuse of fuel products. Fuel substitution is a problem and a concern to the government, as it was to the previous government, and no doubt will be to future governments. Appropriate penalties need to be in place and, indeed, acted upon. In this respect, the government has decided to introduce chemical tracers to concessional fuels before they enter home consumption. The second reading speech states:
The tracer . . . will allow Customs to monitor products in the marketplace to ensure inappropriate usage of concessional fuels does not occur.

And certainly that is a sensible measure. As the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) noted, fuel substitution activities can be hard to detect. The introduction of a marker will make fuel substitution easier to detect. The legislation package is detailed and complicated but I am pleased to note that the government has consulted widely with interested parties. I certainly support this package of bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the previous speaker has explained, the Excise Tariff (Fuel Rates Amendments) Bill 1997 and associated legislation require the addition of a suitable chemical marker to petroleum or petroleum like products that have zero or concessional rates of excise tax applied to them. The reason we feel this is necessary is to combat the financial incentive to use these concessional rate fuel substitutes as substitutes for petroleum products such as petrol or diesel, which are attracting the highest excise taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: With the substitution fuels that we are talking about, such as heating oil and kerosene, a tax is paid at a concessional rate of 7.2c a litre. Solvents, turpentine, white oil and other products, such as dry‐cleaning fluid, attract no tax at all. Obviously, there is an incentive to mix these products with diesel or petrol, which is taxed at higher levels—for example, unleaded petrol and diesel is taxed at the rate of 34.697c a litre and leaded petrol is taxed at the rate of 36.872c a litre.

If you mixed a fifty‐fifty shandy of heating oil and kerosene, taxed at 7.2c a litre, with petrol or diesel, you have a mix of 34c a litre for 50 per cent of the product, and 7c a litre for the other 50 per cent of the product, giving an average excise tax of around 20c a litre. So you would be paying tax of 20c a litre instead of 34c or 35c a litre, which is a saving of 14c or 15c a litre. It does not take much imagination to see where that can lead.

I am told that most fuel in this country is sold at an average profit of about 2.2c a litre. If you can suddenly lift your profit sevenfold from 2c a litre to 14c a litre, then there is a great financial incentive there to do the wrong thing. Semitrailers comfortably hold a thousand litres, and when you multiply that by 14c a litre, you have a profit margin there of $140. Even if you discount that to get the sale, you are still looking at $100 every time you fill up a semitrailer. Let us say they do two kilometres for every litre of fuel. If they are running full bore all of the time, and most of them have to to break even, let alone to make a profit, they could be saving $100 every second day. That translates into about $15,000 to $20,000 a year just on one unit on the road. Even by conservative estimates, you would be looking at a saving of $10,000 per year.

That has many ramifications. First of all, it means people can act illegally to give themselves an unfair price advantage over fuel distributors who are operating legally. In other words, it penalises the honest. This has come about only in recent years because of the tremendous amount of tax that the previous government put on fuel. When we left office in 1983, the excise on fuel federally was of the order of about six cents a litre whereas today it is approaching 36c a litre and hence there is this financial incentive to do the wrong thing.

The trouble is that there has been no real penalty for people who are caught out doing this. Also, it has been very hard, if not impossible, to detect those who are doing it. Of course, had we got into power in 1993 a GST would have been applied to everything. Everything would have been taxed at the same level and so this financial incentive to do the wrong thing would not have existed.

As I say, you cannot detect it chemically, or it is very hard to do so, despite what people might think. Also, it is very hard, if not impossible, to get prosecutions. But putting a chemical marker in, which should have been done years ago, only adds a cost to the fuel, we estimate, of 0.00045c per litre. Therefore, the cost of getting rid of this problem is absolutely negligible.

In the notes that the minister has supplied it says that the Commonwealth will collect an extra $25 million of tax a year by cutting out this practice. The people in my electorate tell me that it is much more prevalent than that. One person who ran some sums past me estimated that the government could be collecting hundreds of millions, up to $300 million. But, on top of that, these people are getting around paying state tax, and it was estimated that New South Wales has lost $7 million a year and Victoria has lost $14 million a year just because of this practice.

This morning I rang one of the people in my electorate who had been complaining to me over the years, Graham Hitchick from Bogan Gate. I said, `How is the problem at the moment? Has it eased off since it is now public knowledge that these bills will be passed and this will become illegal?' He said, `To be quite frank, the problem has gotten worse. It has not eased off at all.' The person in his district who is supplying this fuel is running up and down the road every day supplying hundreds of thousands of litres of this fuel.

He also had another problem in his area. It seems the air force had some jet A1 fuel, similar to kerosene, that was not up to specification, and so the air force sold it in the district for about 25c a litre. It was shandied with normal fuel as a 50‐50 mixture. It makes it very hard for a fellow who is operating honestly to be able to compete with that because their customers say, `You're selling me fuel at such and such a price whereas I can get it from Joe Bloggs down the road at 4c or 5c cents a litre cheaper.' They then take the business away from these honest people. That has been shutting down the little operators in country towns, which is very sad to see.

He made a point also about engine damage as a result of using these fuels. Obviously, it can be very damaging to the modern electronic fuel injected petrol engines, but with some diesel engines it can also be damaging. There are basically two types of diesel engines. One is the pushrod type injector diesel engine such as the Cummins and GM engines, the larger diesel engines, and this blend of fuel has little effect on them. However, with the rotary injector pump diesel engines—the engines in the smaller trucks that run around, such as the Bedfords and Isuzus—the blended fuels that are being used in them are much drier than the straight diesel, which acts as its own lubricant. The blended fuel is causing tremendous damage to the injectors and piston crowns of these engines. It is proving to be a false economy to those who are using this fuel.

I have another constituent who distributes fuel out of Dubbo. I will read the letter that he wrote to me. In 1987, he started off by employing five people and he has built up his business today to employ 54 people. As he says, the customs duty alone on the fuel is $15 million a year, and he and his employees pay $450,000 tax a year.
He has a fleet of 15 modern vehicles to distribute the fuel and he has the latest computer technology. As he says in his letter:
We are we believe a good Australian corporate citizen and are a proud member of the small business community.
He goes on to say:

The reason for this letter to you is to highlight what we see as a real potential threat to the future viability of our business. That is the growth of the blended fuel industry. At this stage, we wish to make it clear that we are not talking about the legal blended fuel alternatives such as ethanol but the shady practice of blending crude oil, sump oil, condensate, refinery bottoms, solvents, heating oil, jet fuel and many other petrol distillate substitutes into petrol and distillate and selling it into the general market to internal combustion engines.

The operators moving into this field are typically here today gone tomorrow operators. They use substandard practices and equipment, quite often flouting all government regulations both State and Federal and making supernormal profits at the expense of the consumer, government, legitimate operators like ourselves and the wider community.
He says:

Over the last few years we have seen the growth of blended fuel as an alternative fuel available to the transport sector. The use of this fuel has grown to the point where it is my belief that all the major transport companies in Dubbo now are obtaining their bulk requirements from the blended market rather than using distillate with full customs duty. This blended fuel is also making inroads into the reseller market as retail service stations are making partial purchases of this sort of fuel.

Now that is a pretty big statement. Dubbo is probably the biggest trucking transport centre in Australia in many ways, certainly in country areas. It is the hub of the west and it is a central point for operators operating out of South Australia, Victoria and Queensland, as well as New South Wales. And he says every major transport company in Dubbo is using blended fuel today.

The reason he has not complained much about it up until now is that the margins selling into these industries are very tight indeed. They tend to be slow payers because they are under financial pressures et cetera. The reason he wrote to me is that they are starting to push this blended fuel into the farming sector, and that is where his concern was. He goes on to say:

. . . legitimate operators like ourselves are being forced out of business by those who choose to use the cheaper blended fuel. It has become a case of join the gang or go out of business. The same is happening in the reseller market as otherwise honest service stations choose to buy a proportion of blended fuel to remain viable and compete against the service stations who sell blended fuel.
Later in his letter, he says:
. . . the Customs Department is aware of the loss of an estimated $300,000,000.00 in government revenue and has failed to have a successful prosecution.

What is of a more disturbing issue to us is the knowledge that an old depot is reopening in Narromine near Dubbo by an organisation well‐known to the Customs Department as a blender. In the past we have not seen blended fuel flowing into the farm market very much with the exception of the Gunnedah area. If the blended fuel starts to flow in the farm market this will have further repercussions for our business viability and your revenue problems. In effect the Government will be paying to the primary production industry the rebate back on the customs duty when it was not paid or only partially paid in the first place.

I think that is an excellent letter in summing up what has been blatantly going on in this country today. It is a great shame that no action has been taken until now. I had a number of representations in past years to the previous government and no action was taken. I am delighted that the previous minister, Geoff Prosser, and the present Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, Chris Ellison, have taken action, which everybody says will work. I cannot stress too much that this use of blended or substitute fuel is very prevalent. It is not something that is going on in an intermittent basis.

The customs department alone has had over 150 complaints in the last two years. The use of this fuel has risen by some estimates by 300 per cent over the last couple of years; it continues to increase and, as I say, the fines have been totally inadequate. In that previous letter where the person mentioned the use in Gunnedah of fuel going on to farms, that instance was where two million litres of avtur were mixed with distillate and sold around the district. It is just going on blatantly and nobody has been able to do anything about it.

I do say that legal blending in some cases is allowed to be used. We have struck that problem in farming areas, particularly in cold areas, where some types of distillate were waxing up early on frosty mornings and it was very hard to start tractor engines. Legally, you can get permission to blend 25 to 50 per cent of heating oil into the distillate. An excise tax is then paid on the heating oil at the full rate of 34c a litre. But while that is legal, most of the operations with blending or substitute are illegal.

It has been stressed to me, too, that when this legislation is passed, Customs must have access for sampling at all areas of the distribution chain, from the point where the chemical marker should have been added, onwards. This sampling must be done at random for it to work. It has also been stressed to me that the chemical marker must be in all solvents; there should be no exemptions whatsoever. For example, solvent 99, as it is called, is a distillate substitute and solvent 13 is a petrol substitute and if these are exempted this practice will go on. Both solvent 99 and solvent 13 are cutting agents used in the manufacturing industry. They are evaporated off and used as a fuel medium in, for example, the paint manufacturing industry. They can be purchased for about 30c a litre and mixed in with fuels where the tax alone is of the order of 34c or 35c a litre.

It is also essential, as the legislation provides, to have the chemical marker in on‐shore condensate. I know it is exempted for off‐shore condensate, but a lot of the problem in my area is the condensate coming down from south‐west Queensland. One estimate I had was of 600,000 litres a week going through Narromine alone down to Sydney and being made into other products which are then mixed with diesel. So I do stress that the chemical marker must go into on‐shore condensate otherwise this legislation will not work.

The penalties up until now for the improper use of blending agents have been virtually zero. There has been no disincentive for anyone to do the right thing. The penalties for people that would be doing this start, as I understand it, at the $50,000 level, except for more minor offences. So we will be able to detect it and put on proper penalties and, if it is shown that these penalties are not sufficient, perhaps the legislation should be amended to increase these penalties at a later date.

I just want to again mention briefly the engine damage that can be done. It blocks filters and injections—the tips of the injectors can actually melt in some cases. It can cause irreparable engine damage. It can make engines hard to start because the thicker blending agents will not atomise properly and it causes black smoke out of the exhausts. But, perhaps, more important is the safety angle. The flashpoint of diesel is around 61 degrees Centigrade, although some companies have it up as high as 64 degrees Centigrade. But kerosene, one of the common blending agents, is as low as 38 degrees Centigrade.

You get truck operators checking the diesel levels in their tanks by using the naked flame of a match and we have had cases with blended fuels where there have been explosions. You can imagine what can happen in a truck accident. There is a much increased chance of getting an explosion and if the driver was trapped in the cabin he or she could be incinerated alive. In July two years ago there was a person seriously injured in South Australia who was welding a fuel tank and thought there was diesel in it; it turned out to be one of these blended agents where the flash point was much lower. So there is a very great safety angle here. The legislation, I believe, is worth bringing in and implementing just from the safety angle alone.

I do compliment particularly the previous minister, Geoff Prosser—under whom most of this legislation was put together—for bringing this in. It was something that was sorely needed. It is a very simple thing and it can be implemented at low cost. I believe it will not only be beneficial to revenue, but will help small business and improve the safety of the transport industry in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to sum up on behalf of the government. This package of nine bills is designed to give effect to our announcement in the last budget that we would be cracking down on fuel substitution. I thank the members who have contributed in the debate on this issue today, particularly the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly), the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) and the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), who raised matters of vital importance to their constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: It has certainly been a longstanding and well‐accepted policy of successive governments that, where excise is imposed on petroleum products, differential rates of duty are applied on the basis of the intended end use of the product. The highest rate of customs and excise duty is imposed on fuels, such as gasoline and automotive diesel oil, for on‐road transport use.

The specifications for some concessional and zero‐rated petroleum products, such as solvents, may be very similar to those for on‐road fuels, particularly automotive diesel oil. Accordingly, substitution of lower duty products for on‐road uses is, unfortunately, attractive to unscrupulous operators. For example, if product declared as a solvent at the terminal gate of a major oil company is subsequently blended with automotive diesel oil by a party in the retail distribution system, the windfall gain from this fraud is quite substantial.

The 1997‐98 budget estimated that the measures underpinned by this legislative package will lead to increased revenue in the order of $25 million in a full year. It is worth bearing in mind, as the member for Parkes has rightly stressed, that use of these fuels can greatly harm engine performance and expose consumers to great danger as the blends containing substituted fuel may have a much lower flash point than a proper diesel.

We decided that the best way to minimise these practices is to require the introduction of chemical tracers to concessional fuels before they enter home consumption. The tracer will allow Customs to monitor products in the marketplace to ensure inappropriate usage of concessional fuels does not occur. The presence of the marker will make illegal substitutions simple to detect, both by Customs and by participants in the market who wish to do so. There has been very good cooperation and consultation with industry with regard to this whole approach that the government has adopted.

In conclusion, I reiterate that the government is introducing these measures to increase compliance with long‐established excise taxation policy, as well as to address loopholes in existing excise legislation where it does not deliver this policy. This is obviously going to be of benefit to the government, in terms of collecting the proper excise revenue legislated by the parliament; to consumers, in terms of safer petroleum products; and, let us not forget, to those honest participants who form the vast majority of the petroleum products distribution retail system who wish to compete on level terms. I will table the supplementary explanatory memoranda.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move government amendments Nos 1 to 8:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 15, page 5, description of goods falling to item 11, omit "petroleum condensate" (twice occurring), substitute "condensate".

(2) Schedule 1, item 15, page 5, description of goods falling to item 11, omit "semi‐refined liquid petroleum products other than lubricating oils", substitute "partly refined liquid petroleum products other than lubricants (including lubricant base oils), hydraulic oils, transformer oils".
(3) Schedule 1, item 15, page 5, omit subitem 11(A), substitute:

ROW.ENTRY: Kerosene for use as a fuel in aircraft

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Schedule 1, item 15, page 6, omit subitem 11(D), substitute:

ROW.ENTRY: Fuel oil having the characteristics set out in subsection 3(4)

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Schedule 1, item 15, page 7, description of goods falling to subitem 11(E), omit "Petroleum condensate", substitute "Condensate".

(6) Schedule 1, item 15, page 9, omit "Other refined or partly refined petroleum products other than lubricating oils or bitumen", substitute "Other refined or partly refined petroleum products other than lubricants (including lubricant base oils), hydraulic oils, transformer oils or bitumen".
(7) Schedule 1, item 15, page 9, omit subparagraph 11(I)(1)(a), substitute:

ROW.ENTRY: Diesel fuel, and gasoline, on which customs or excise duty has been paid, recovered by a recycling process not being a process of refining

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Schedule 1, item 18, page 11, omit subitem 17(B), substitute:

ROW.ENTRY: Condensate produced in a State or Territory or inside the outer limits of the territorial sea of Australia other than condensate produced from a prescribed source

SPEECH.PARA: Five of the eight amendments circulated are technical; the three that are not refer to amendment 4, on fuel oil. This is an amendment dispensing with the requirement to chemically mark fuel oil. This product is jet black in colour, and industry has pointed out that the introduction of a chemical marker would be redundant. The proposed amendments respond to these industry concerns.
Secondly, amendment 6 to item 11.1 in the tariff item 15 of schedule 1 to the bill at page 9 is a technical amendment to clarify the range of oils intended not to be covered by this item.

Thirdly, amendment 8 limits the application of the fuel substitution regime to condensate which is produced onshore only. Discussion with industry confirmed that the current production and handling methods of condensate produced offshore limit the potential for fuel substitution practices in respect of this condensate.
