TITLE.XREF: FAMILY COURT OF WESTERN AUSTRALIA (ORDERS OF REGISTRARS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to extend my profound thanks to the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who has given me the opportunity to speak on the Family Court of Western Australia (Orders of Registrars) Bill 1997—because of a double‐booking in the other chamber, I suspect. He has said he is going to exact a price in the future—no pun intended—so I am looking forward to that.

SPEECH.PARA: Although this bill was born of a landmark case in the Family Court of Australia earlier this year, it is not a contentious one and, to my mind, it is fairly straightforward. These amendments are of significance, however, to the constituents of Curtin, who will be adversely affected if this measure is not passed. The Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), in his second reading speech, observed that this bill will have no significant financial impact on the Commonwealth. That may be true, but it will have substantial social consequences for the many hundreds of Western Australians affected by the Family Court of Australia's decision in the Horne case in February this year.

Notwithstanding the other important pieces of legislation that have been dealt with in this place this year, it is lamentable that the government has waited for more than six months before bringing on the debate and proposing this measure. Even the Western Australian state parliament, with its inability to properly manage its own legislative program, has managed to act before now and introduce complementary legislation.

However, the bulk of those affected by the Family Court decision will not have their consent orders validated by the state legislation because Western Australia does not have the constitutional authority to validate retrospectively the exercise of Commonwealth judicial power. This parliament is the only one that can do that by passing amendments to the Family Law Act.
As was pointed out during debate on the complementary legislation in the Western Australian state parliament:

The door was open for people to behave improperly when the decision was handed down by the full court on 13 February (1997). That door will remain open for people to behave improperly until such time as (the) federal parliament enacts legislation.
This bill should have been here much earlier, as I have indicated. The bill simply seeks to maintain the status quo of family law in Western Australia.

By correcting a technical flaw in the current legislation, it serves to realign the powers of the Family Court of Western Australia with that of the Commonwealth. Section 41 of the Family Law Act 1975 invites each state to form their own family court but specifies that in all key respects these courts must possess the characteristics of the Family Court of Australia. I repeat: in all key respects a state family court must possess the same characteristics as that of the original Commonwealth Family Court.

The Family Court of Western Australia has been invested with Commonwealth jurisdiction under the Marriage Act and the Family Law Act since its genesis on 1 June 1976. Mr Anthony Dickey, in his book entitled Family Law, writes:
By providing for the creation of the state family courts, it was envisaged that many of the problems resulting from a divided family law jurisdiction could be avoided.
Indeed, it is because of the fragmented spheres of duty in Australian family law that this bill has become necessary. As Finlay and Bailey‐Harris noted in a publication that appeared in 1989:
The increasing mobility and homogeneity of the Australian people makes it desirable that to a maximum extent legislation affecting the family should be uniform throughout Australia.
It is perhaps regrettable then that Western Australia has been the only state to take up the Commonwealth's offer to establish its own Family Court.

Section 37A of the Family Law Act 1975 provided the registrars of the Commonwealth Family Court with specific powers. This included the authority to make consent orders and to register parenting plans following the breakdown of a nuptial relationship. Western Australian registrars have been issuing the same orders not realising that the original transfer of authority from the judges to them was not the subject of any power of review by the judges of that court.

The consequence of this is that all orders made by registrars in the Western Australian family courts since 16 December 1985 are null and void. The ramifications of this finding should not be underestimated. The majority of people who file applications with the Family Court of Western Australia choose to negotiate a consent order to settle property disputes as opposed to having a contested hearing before a judge.

If this amendment before us today had not been proposed most of these consent orders would have remained deficient. It is for this reason that the retrospective nature of this amendment is entirely supportable. I made clear my position on the implementation of retrospective legislation many times in this place where it imposes a burden, but this certainly is not in that category. It is not appropriate for this or any parliament to introduce retrospective legislation where it harms or takes things away from people. This legislation, as I have indicated, is not about taking something from anyone. On the contrary, it endeavours to declare effective those consent orders that were agreed to by all parties concerned in Western Australia but that are now proved to be ineffective because of an oversight.

Clause 5 in the bill indicates that the statutory rights and liabilities of all persons are the same as those that would have been created by the relevant ineffective order if it had been a valid order made by the Family Court of Western Australia in the exercise of its federal family law jurisdiction. That is straightforward and eminently reasonable. In the meantime, as the Western Australian Attorney‐General has observed, registrars in Western Australia have ceased to act as registrars in the issuing of consent orders and instead have acted in their capacity as magistrates to ensure that consent orders made since the court decision have been valid. The Attorney‐General of Western Australia noted also that this is entirely acceptable as `they are able validly to deal with those orders because a proper delegation is available to them and magistrates can be reviewed.'

This bill is not an issue in states rights. It will not see the erosion of the authority of the Western Australian Family Court. Rather it seeks to maintain a uniform legislative framework—an area in which Australia has a poor track record.

Mr D. H. O'Neil, the minister in the Western Australian government who enacted the establishment of the Western Australian Family Court, outlined the rationale behind the move in parliament on 21 October 1975. He noted that a state based Family Law Court would:

enable the state to continue to exercise jurisdiction in family law matters which would otherwise have been removed into the Federal Court of Australia with the opportunity of retaining complementary action with other responsibilities in the areas of welfare and counselling services.

Several legal academics have observed that this is one of the more positive enduring legacies of the introduction of the Western Australian Family Court. The authors of a book entitled Family Law in Australia wrote that our state based Family Law Court avoids both the practical and jurisdictional difficulties that are part and parcel of our fractured family law legislation. This was reinforced in the Federal Court last year when Chief Justice Michael Black said:

The history of federal, state and territory . . . courts in Australia . . . shows that cooperation can avoid jurisdictional conflict and that conflict is not the inevitable consequence of the existence in a federation of more than one system of courts.

The bill will not impact on existing family law statutes in other states. It merely legitimises the current state of play and will mean that the administration of justice in Western Australia remains close to the people it is meant to assist. Nor does it contain any of the flaws of the state legislation that caused concern within the legal profession.

Clause 7 of the Western Australian legislation related to contempt proceedings and was identified as being an important deficiency in the bill. However, there is no such inclusion in the legislation before this chamber. The Law Society of Western Australia has observed in its draft advice that `it seems to adequately address the difficulties raised by the full court decision.' As I suggested earlier, the bill is not a controversial one. When section 41 of the principal Family Law Act was introduced by the then Labor Party government some 20 years ago, it was endorsed by the conservative parties because it was seen to facilitate cooperative federalism.

In the same way, I anticipate that this amendment will garner the support of all in this place irrespective of their political persuasions. The bill is both sensible and necessary. It will correct a drafting error to ensure that Western Australian registrars are empowered in the same terms as Family Court registrars elsewhere. I commend the bill to the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Randall, Don, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Family Court of Western Australia (Orders of Registrars) Bill 1997 I put on the record that my interest in this bill is not only as a Western Australian but also as a committee member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I have had an opportunity to visit the Family Court of Western Australia and see its operations and I am pleased to be able to speak in relation to this fine institution.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make some brief comments on the bill because it addresses issues which have caused some concern to people not only in my electorate of Swan—I have been contacted by a few constituents with concerns about this matter—but also to the wider Western Australian community who have had dealings with the Family Court of Western Australia. Much of what I am going to say has been mentioned by the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) but I would like to show that there is certainly agreement across the chamber on this because it is a non‐contentious bill.

The Family Court of Western Australia (Orders of Registrars) Bill 1997 seeks to rectify the previous legislation which allowed registrars of the Family Court of Western Australia to make certain rulings or consent orders which were found by the full court of the Family Court to be invalid. These rulings involved family law matters of visitation, property and financial settlements, child guardianship and numerous other aspects of the family law. Western Australia, as has already been stated, is a unique state in that when the Family Law Act of 1975 was passed each state was given the opportunity to establish its own family court but only Western Australia did so. As a result, the Family Court of Western Australia exercises federal jurisdiction and state jurisdiction.

Following Horne v. Horne, which drew attention to the invalidity of certain consent orders, I received, as I said, several calls and communications from constituents who were concerned that their settlements and agreements might be invalid. There were quite a few people who were afraid that they would have to go back to court and that considerable financial and emotional costs would have to be expended to go through the processes again. However, the Commonwealth government and the Western Australian state government did immediately recognise the ramifications of Horne v. Horne. We are now seeing the Commonwealth and the state government of Western Australia working closely on this legislative solution to the family law problem to ensure efficiency of law and fairness to the people of Western Australia.

I point out that there are people, who are no longer in Western Australia but who were affected by the findings of Horne v. Horne, who will have the same statutory rights as Western Australians similarly affected.

I understand orders are not being made at present and that lawyers are advising their clients to wait until this legislation is enacted. That is the reason for some urgency in terms of this legislation. It is essential that we get on with the business of this bill before us to alleviate the concerns of the very many Western Australians who are affected by the full court decision.

The full court of the Family Court decided, following the Horne v. Horne case in February this year, that consent orders made since the mid-1980s by registrars of the Family Court of Western Australia were not valid, as has been stated. The case came about when one of the parties sought to set aside an order made by a registrar with regard to a property dispute. The appellant argued that neither the Family Court Act of Western Australia nor the Family Law Act of the Commonwealth delegated the requisite judicial power to registrars of the Family Court of Western Australia to make such consent orders.

The full court of the Family Court decided that the registrars certainly did not have the power to make consent orders. The court's decision was based on the absence of any statutory provision or, in other words, rule of court, under the Western Australian legislation that provides parties with the right to seek review of the decisions of the registrars. Clearly, in matters of family law, as with other areas of law, there needs to be some mechanism by which decisions can be reviewed.

It is important to note that the full court's decision is not expected to have any ramifications for the exercise of powers by the registrars of the Family Court of Australia. However, decisions of registrars of the Family Court of Western Australia made since the 1980s have been put in question.

This bill, as I have stated and as the member for Curtin has stated, will overcome the technical legal problem by ensuring that all affected people obtain enforceable statutory family law rights and liabilities that mirror the rights and liabilities that would have been created by valid registrars orders. To ensure the situation being addressed by this bill does not occur again, there will be provision for delegation to registrars and review of their decisions by the courts.

It can be safely said that family law is one of the most emotional and volatile areas of law. Sadly, in my electorate of Swan, I see the results of family breakdown far too often when people contact my office for assistance with regard to child support especially, and with regard to visitation of their children when one of the parents is ignoring rulings made by the court. At other times they need to know who else can help them other than the courts. These people do not want to relive the circumstances which saw them go to the Family Court in the first place and we have to ensure that everything can be done to make this legislation, and future decisions made by the court, absolutely watertight.

As I said earlier, I understand that orders are not being made at present and lawyers are advising their clients to wait until this legislation is enacted. Court cases have been adjourned and people are waiting for this problem to be resolved quickly so they can get on with their lives.

Because of the uncertainty caused by the Horne v. Horne decision, injunctions have been lodged on settlements of property and finances, which is a disappointing situation for those involved. People are ceasing to adhere to orders of visitation and of child support while they believe the orders to be invalid. This is affecting the children who are all too often the innocent victims of matters to do with family law.

The Child Support Agency has reported numerous instances where parents have contacted the agency asking for their payments to be suspended because of the invalidation of the orders under which the payment schedules were made. These parents will, of course, have to pay back monies once the legislation has been passed, but in the meantime the children are losing out.

In another instance, a mother of two children has become very worried since learning that her custody order was signed by a registrar. This woman had already been through a protracted court hearing involving her violent ex-husband who had also sought custody. This woman was understandably seriously concerned that her ex-husband would feel that he had a right to custody in some interim type arrangement while the matter of this particular order was investigated because of its invalidation. This is very undesirable at a time when the security of the woman and that of her children are at risk.

There are many people who are in limbo waiting for this legislation to be passed. Others are waiting for their own cases to be heard and their dealings with the Family Court to be finalised. They are hoping that the associated emotional turmoil and stress can be finalised.

Finally, this bill, by creating new and enforceable statutory family law rights, addresses the problems causing anguish to so many Western Australians following the invalidation of the orders. In also acknowledging the cooperation of the Western Australian state government, I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the Family Court of Western Australia (Orders of Registrars) Bill 1997 . As the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) foreshadowed, we do not have any difficulty with this legislation. I will indicate briefly what has led to this legislation. As previous speakers have indicated, it arose out of a case, Horne v. Horne. The husband appealed against the deputy registrar's order. He alleged, amongst other things, that the Registrar and Deputy Registrar of the Family Court of Western Australia did not have the power to make such orders.

SPEECH.PARA: In Horne v. Horne, the full court of the Family Court held that the consent orders which had been made by the deputy registrar were made without jurisdiction and were invalid. The deputy registrar was purportedly acting under family law rules. However, the full court found that, whilst rules could be made for practice and procedure, this did not enable rules to be made which did not provide for the review of the registrar's decision by a judge, by way of a new hearing on all the issues of fact and law. A right of judicial review of decisions of officers like registrars, who exercise delegated judicial power, was seen by the court as a substantive right which could not be impinged upon by rules made under a practice and procedure power.The appeal did not challenge the powers of registrars operating under the Family Court of Australia. This piece of legislation rectifies that situation by providing new rights and obligations to the parties, and is, as I said, supported.

I have to confess that my interest in family law really started with an interest in child support. You cannot fix child support without getting the family law issues correct. As the honourable member for Curtin pointed out, when the Family Court was being set up, each state had the opportunity to set up their own family court. Western Australia was the only state that exercised that option. My natural instinct would be to see a completely centralised court, although I have had cause to reflect on that. The Family Court of Western Australia is a state based court.

In the debate on this bill, I indicate that I support some of the initiatives being undertaken by the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) in the family law area. The first one deals with section 121, the so‐called secrecy provisions of the Family Law Act. At the moment, the legislation makes it next to impossible for the media to report the proceedings of the Family Court, whether they are in Western Australia or in any other state.

Whilst that may have been a provision that attracted a lot of support in 1975, we need to recognise that our Australian society has moved on. It is no longer extraordinary in any family to have a family member who has been divorced or separated. I do not believe that the children suffer, as they may once have suffered, with the so‐called stigma of family break‐up. I am sure they are not the winners out of family break‐up, but I do not believe we can talk about the same social stigma.

BREAK.PARA: The Attorney‐General has commissioned a report, the so‐called McCall report, looking into section 121 of the Family Law Act—the secrecy provisions—and they are recommending what I would call some very modest changes. From my own party's perspective we do not seem to be handling these initiatives in a very proactive way. If I have a criticism about the McCall recommendations it is that they do not go far enough. I do not really believe that there is a need for a blanket secrecy provision. I do not believe that we need to protect children from information that their parents may be splitting up. In fact, I have confidence in the procedures that operate in any other court. That is, if the parties to a matter wish to have their names suppressed, an application is made to the judge and that application is decided on its merits.

This secrecy provision—with great respect—operates not for ordinary citizens or their children in this land; it operates for the benefit of the wealthy and, dare I say, members of parliament to ensure that these matters are not reported on. I think that the secrecy provisions have had a most adverse impact on the Family Court. Its proceedings are little understood and the normal scrutiny of the operations of all courts that you expect in a democracy—whether it be of a magistrate's court, a family court or, indeed, the High Court—are denied. I think that it is bad for democracy, and I think it is even worse for the operations of a Family Court.

So I would say this to the Attorney‐General and to honourable government backbenchers across the table: when considering the government's response to the McCall report, I would urge you to go further, to remove the secrecy provisions from the Family Court and then allow parties to hearings before the court to make an application to the judge and allow that judge then to decide those issues on their merits.

But, as I said, I welcome the initiative of the Attorney‐General in this matter. I would hope that my party would eventually take a very positive attitude to those initiatives, although I cannot recall us being given an opportunity to date to discuss these matters.

The other interesting aspect that I should raise in this debate about the Western Australia Family Court is, of course, that it does not have its own court counsellors. Again, the Attorney‐General in a most important speech in October of last year signalled his intention to examine—and he has now put a discussion paper out—the possibility of removing all non‐judicial functions from the Family Court.

In Western Australia there are court counsellors—in fact, I have been over there—but they are counsellors who are employed by the relevant state department and they just happen to operate in the Family Court environment. In New Zealand, where there is a similar situation, you have five district court judges operating with a family court warrant and that court has absolutely no counsellors of its own. In fact, they are all private counsellors. The court has the money to requisition those counselling resources as they require.

That is a far better system because—with no disrespect in this regard to the Family Court judges—I think that they are better judges than they are managers of non‐judicial services. The more we can focus them on their strictly judicial responsibilities, the better.

I thought it was interesting that we had a contribution from the member for Swan (Mr Randall), who is a member of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. There has been a very important decision recently brought up in the national newspapers that does have an effect in the family law area, and that is the so‐called Brandy case. In this instance, the decisions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission were determined to be exercising judicial power and, therefore, those decisions were struck down.

You might ask, quite rightly, how this impacts on family law. I should first respond to the Attorney‐General by correcting a statement he made in the House, and that is to say that I have read the Brandy decision at length a number of times. But if there is one real reform that we need to embrace in this family law area, particularly in relation to the Family Court, it is establishing a new tribunal, with arbitration powers, where parties can bring property, residency and contact issues without legal representation and have those matters arbitrated, not according to procedures that you would expect if judicial power were being exercised, but under an administrative tribunal arrangement similar to the Small Claims Tribunal in our state or the tenants and residency tribunal that has been established in our state and in a number of other state jurisdictions.

This decision, I regret to say, has been interpreted as removing the ability of the Commonwealth to establish such a no‐frills family tribunal exercising arbitration powers in these matters. If that is the case, it is a most regrettable decision by the High Court. I am most loath to criticise the High Court, but what they are failing to consider is this: whilst it is true that the rule of law is absolutely fundamental to our human rights infrastructure in Australia, where you have the case that citizens cannot afford to exercise those rights, then that is justice denied, that is human rights denied and it makes a mockery of the rule of law. Those things must be precious to us.

I have often been accused of wanting to abolish the Family Court of Australia. Nothing could be further from the truth. We will always have those citizens in our society who will want to opt for that as a mechanism for resolving their disputes. You will also have other categories of cases, particularly where there is clearly demonstrated domestic violence, where the issues must be determined by the courts of the land. But I sincerely believe we need to provide citizens with choice.

Not everyone wishes to have their family affairs sorted out in the court, because it becomes such an expensive exercise. In so many cases I can report that more money was spent on legal representation than was ever distributed between the parties or set aside for the future of the children of the family being separated. This is an absolute tragedy. I say to the Attorney‐General that I certainly support the initiative as far as secrecy is concerned. I believe it is appropriate that we look at this issue about the non‐judicial functions within the Family Court and I can see that the creation of a magistracy will provide some relief, but that does not really provide the critical solution.

I do not think we can avoid forever looking seriously at setting up such a tribunal. The interesting thing is that because the Western Australian Family Court is set up under state jurisdiction, it is much easier to actually set up such a tribunal in Western Australia. As I said, I would normally have felt that in looking at the history of the establishment of the Family Court and Western Australia opting to exercise its right to have a state family court, I perhaps would have been a bit negative about that. I think it is positive. I say then that if, at the Commonwealth level, we are so constrained that we cannot set up this no‐frills family tribunal arbitrating decisions, then maybe we need to consider vacating this area and, indeed, encouraging the states again to look at this opportunity.

No matter how much I support some of these reforms or initiatives that the Attorney‐General is currently contemplating, we cannot avoid the really tough issues. The biggest issue is that too many people are being forced into getting legal representation and slugging their cases out in front of deputy registrars, registrars or judicial registrars, not to mention magistrates and, indeed, judges. We need to reserve the judges for the highest level of judicial decision making and not squander what is a precious human rights resource. We really do have to update our thinking, particularly with the next millennium coming upon us, to make sure that the law, if not in all areas then in this most important family law area, is accessible to ordinary citizens. That ought to be the test, for either a government or an opposition: how they are going to deal with these matters.

I did say that my original interest in all this came through looking at the child support scheme. Of course, some of the orders that can be obtained from deputy registrars relate to that scheme. I note that there has been speculation in the paper about the government announcing reform of the child support scheme, and probably today's Courier‐Mail has the most detailed information. Let me say that I know that there has been disappointment expressed that they do not go far enough—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 12.12 p.m. to 12.26 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was talking about the article about child support in the Courier‐Mail . A lot of people have said it is disappointing. I agree, but I also think it is important for the government to announce the changes as quickly as possible. I think the real danger is thinking that you can, in either family law or child support, announce changes and then box them in concrete for a great period of time. A scheme like the child support scheme is a dynamic one that needs to be constantly monitored and constantly finetuned. I would have hoped that for the government the starting point might have been the recommendations that the joint committee made. Hopefully, in the not too distant future, we could move on beyond those recommendations and implement even further reform.

BREAK.PARA: In conclusion, I certainly support these changes that provide certainty for consent orders by registrars in the Western Australian Family Court. I have indicated my support for a number of the initiatives that the Attorney‐General has commenced or has undertaken. I sincerely hope that my party will have an opportunity to examine these and consider them in detail and move along into the next millennium taking up the challenge of reforming family law. I support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to discuss the Family Court of Western Australia (Orders of Registrars) Bill because it is of particular interest to me. It gives me an opportunity to discuss something that has always been close to my heart. That is federalism and how it came about via our constitution that a state of affairs could occur where the federal parliament must be legislating in order to give effect to decisions and actions taken by a state parliament. It can all be traced back to section 51 of the constitution:

SPEECH.PARA: The parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:‐
(xxi): marriage
(xxii) Divorce and matrimonial causes; and in relation thereto, parental rights, and the custody and guardianship of infants . . .

With that power, the federal government set up the Family Law Act. At that time, the states were given an opportunity to set up their own court. Of all the states, Western Australia was the only one to do so. It is quite obvious that the parochial feelings in Western Australia are strongly against any sort of federal intervention and strongly support their own state's rights.

I think Richard Court in the article `The rebuilding of the federation and audited history of state powers and responsibilities usurped by the Commonwealth in the years since federation'—notice the colourful language—pretty well sums up the attitude of the Premier in Western Australia to federal powers of governments.

However, one must query the relevance in that instance of the states. As the Commonwealth gains more and more powers, how relevant then does the law‐making ability of the states become? I noticed recently that Bob Carr already seeks to reduce the number of members in the New South Wales state parliament. In fact, he could almost reduce them to nothing if he was serious about saving expenses to taxpayers and not about representation. Is it really just a rort in New South Wales or does he have a legitimate point about representation and the role of the states coming into the next millennium?

Over time, the states have given more and more power in this area to the federal government and it has worked quite nicely. I noticed that the member for Chifley (Mr Price) wanted to go back to some sort of furthering of state powers in these matters. I hasten to remind him that it was cross‐jurisdictional issues that led to the states giving more and more powers to the federal government.

It is quite inappropriate that an offence under the Family Law Act in Victoria when the victims are in Tasmania and the perpetrators are in New South Wales cannot be prosecuted. AVOs cannot be enforced and all sorts of custodial and financial responsibility can be avoided by simply crossing state boundaries. There was a requirement for a federal, cohesive and comprehensive family law act. That is in place but it needs to be reassessed. Given the continuing evolution of our society, legislation will always need to be reassessed. It will always need to be amended, improved and updated to reflect current social trends.

I noticed in the Daily Telegraph yesterday the headline `A nation of bastards'. It actually got played right around the world. In fact, we were on APP, and it ended up in France with pictures of newsagents holding up our Daily Telegraph to the world, portraying Australia as a nation of bastards where one in three are born outside of marriage. That is a social trend in Australia. The commitment to marriage or the legal obligations of marriage have become so onerous—we are given such a terrible view in the media of incidents arising out of the Family Law Court—that a significant proportion of society is steering away from this traditional institution that is part of the fabric of our society.

Whilst contemplating social trends, and where society is going, I listened to Norm Swan's Life Matters program. He was talking about a report from the United States which had surveyed over 90,000 children from homes with two parents and from homes with a single parent. They felt the distinction was scientifically justifiable. There are a number of problems associated with lone parent families, the raising of their children and their subsequent involvement in terms of where they got their values and social consciences from.

It is something that society has to address. We have to study it and research it. It is something that our laws need to address. It is also something that needs to be in the national interests of Australia. I do not think we can keep coming back to the federal government to solve problems in Western Australia because Richard Court finds himself unable to fall in line with the rest of Australia. He seeks still to see the states retain some independence for their own financial ability.

BREAK.PARA: The changes that we have seen in society in recent years have been extraordinary. There is a tendency not to get married. There is a trend towards de facto relationships, and a trend to not stay in a marriage or a relationship that is difficult. There is also a trend to go it alone and to raise children as a single parent. This has consequences throughout the fabric of society for what was the traditional role of females: to stay at home and do a lot of voluntary work. I do not think for a minute that females who stay at home do not work; they do an incredible amount for their neighbourhood, for their community and for the voluntary organisations of our nation.

It is the effect on those voluntary hours due to females entering the workplace—and I have no intention of leaving it—that I am interested in. I speak firmly for female choice. I strongly believe that females should always have a choice, but the fact is that those voluntary hours that females contribute, whilst they maintain a traditional role at home, are lost. The implications for society are quite significant, and the implications for families in the future are quite significant also.

We tend to look at institutions such as the family law court, at alternative dispute resolution, at counselling services, at a number of other institutions and at government provided services to fill in the gaps. I do not think they will ever adequately replace what has been lost, but certainly it is a matter of feeling our way to the new society that is shaping up into the next millennium.

It also has major implications in terms of cross-generational interaction. Often, people now are separated from their families. Young children do not have a close relationship with their grandparents or do not have a high exposure to young children and babies. Consequently, when the women of today are handed their first child, it is quite a novel experience and possibly the only such infant that they have ever held in their lives. That does have significant implications for society. It is simply a trend. It is something that we must go on addressing by being responsive to social trends and trying, through legislation, to keep up with social mores, choices and activities.

The member for Chifley also raised the issue of the child support scheme and the difficulties that a lot of people experience with the scheme. It certainly is nowhere near as responsive as a traditional family with a husband on a wage and a wife at home and a guarantee of support. It just does not happen that way. I do not think the child support scheme in any way hopes to replace the type of support that is available in that situation; it merely is a financial administrator. The only support that it can give is financial. Again, that still leaves a lot of problems out there to be resolved.

The legal process through which we put people who once had a relationship that was close enough at some stage to produce a child needs reforming. We put them through a process in the family law courts where they will not even speak to each other except through lawyers. That says a lot about the process and the need to reform that process.

Certainly, these people will still be the parents of that child long after the initial two years of separation have passed and when all the anger and the angst and the revenge have been worked through. Certainly, at the child's 18th birthday party, at its 21st, at its engagement, at its wedding and at the birth of its children, those parents still have an obligation and a relationship with their child. That needs to be considered whenever you are making any changes to the family law court.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that it has been a wide ranging debate but I feel it incumbent on the chair to remind the honourable member for Lindsay that the long title of the bill is:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Bill for an Act relating to certain ineffective orders of Registrars of the Family Court of Western Australia
If she could direct her remarks to the content of the bill, it would be more helpful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those orders are orders of consent. They are orders that a mother and a father of a child have agreed to. It is that whole relationship and the items which they agreed to and how subsequently that relationship has broken down so that they want to take advantages of loopholes in the legislation to get out of that situation which have led to the requirement for this piece of legislation.

BREAK.PARA: It is no longer a situation where a father and a mother have control of their parenting rights and responsibilities. Once this process takes hold and once they have been through this inordinate process, that initial relationship is broken down to such an extent that there is a requirement to come back to this parliament to legislate, to ensure that actions taken by a court, in all honesty and with all good intentions, can be enforced.

It is a major problem for society. There are a number of social trends that have yet to be addressed. I imagine that we will be back in a very short time to have another look at the family law of this nation. It is something about which we cannot be parochial. It is in Australia's national interest that we come to some form of social understanding, where the families of tomorrow can integrate and provide all the services and support that we have come to expect from families of yore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Court of Western Australia (Orders of Registrars) Bill is a small and concise piece of legislation which has been crafted by the Attorney‐General of Australia (Mr Williams) to meet a particular need which resulted from a decision of the full court of the Family Court of Australia in the matter of the case of Horne v. Horne, which was a case taken to the full court of the Family Court on appeal from the Family Court of Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It ought to be noted that this legislation does not affect the Family Court of Australia. It merely refers to the Family Court of Western Australia, and it is a cooperative attempt to remedy a defect in the provisions of the Family Court of Western Australia. The Western Australian parliament has processed legislation designed to provide a state remedy in so far as the state parliament has the capacity to do so, and it is necessary for similar legislation to be passed through this place.

In the case of Horne v. Horne, a concern was expressed that the consent order made by a registrar in that court had no force or effect because that consent order was not subject to the review of a court. The full court of the Family Court of Australia comprised Justices Fogarty, Lindenmeyer and Moore. They held that whether or not the judges of the Family Court of Western Australia had power to delegate to its registrars the power to make such order, the order here was invalid, as any such delegation was not the subject of any power for review by the judges of that court. So not only were people in the situation of the litigants in Horne v. Horne in trouble but many consent orders in Western Australia were placed in jeopardy as a result of this decision of the full court of the Family Court of Australia.

The lives of parliamentarians and ministers would be simpler if the courts did not intrude and upset what everyone thought was a reasonable legislative or administrative framework. The simple fact of the matter in our system of government is that we do have checks and balances. It is appropriate that people do have redress to go to the courts when they are aggrieved. The situation in this case is that the husband, having agreed to a consent order, decided to contest the right of the deputy registrar to make it. In a sense, he was seeking to have his cake and eat it as well. At the end of the day, there has been a responsibility placed on the Western Australian parliament and on this parliament to remedy the situation, to ensure that people are not disadvantaged as a result of the decision of the full court of the Family Court in the case of Horne v. Horne.

The purpose of this bill is to enable affected people to obtain enforceable statutory family law rights and responsibilities that would have been created by valid registrar orders without attempting to validate the invalid orders made. Some people might say that we are playing with words, but what the legislation does is not to invalidate what is invalid but rather to create a situation where people are not disadvantaged by the decision of the court in Horne v. Horne. In doing so, the bill proposes to create statutory rights and liabilities which are identical to the terms of the invalid orders.

This bill, as I said, will complement the Western Australian legislation. That is why it is being put forward quickly. We are hopeful that the other place will process this legislation and give it the priority that it deserves, because a large number of people in Western Australia are disadvantaged, if not as a result of this particular case, then as a result of the poor or inadequate attempt to give registrars power to make decisions which are not subject to judicial review.

Once these bills are passed, parties affected by invalid orders will not need to take any additional court action to enforce their family law rights. As a lawyer, I can understand that some lawyers do see it as an advantage to go before the courts constantly. I am very pleased that the government has put the interests of litigants and partners to a broken marriage to the fore. They have ensured that, with this legislation being carried in conjunction with the Western Australian bill, people will not have to go back before the court, to take additional court action to enforce their family law rights.

There are situations at the moment where people did think they had valid orders. Those orders are no longer valid, so there is a provision for pandemonium to reign supreme were this legislation not to pass, and pass quickly. I am confident that the government will receive the support of the opposition to ensure that this occurs. The purpose of our amendments is also to put beyond doubt the application of criminal sanctions to certain conduct. If enacted, the amendments will also correct a minor omission in subclause 4(4) of the bill.

This legislation is important. It is not very long. It is legislation, however, which is vital and necessary to ensure that people who have been disadvantaged as a result of the decision of the full court of the Family Court of Australia that the delegation to the registrar was ineffective are not disadvantaged and that their position is restored to one where they will be in the same position were the orders made valid and not invalid.

I have spoken a little longer than I had planned in order to give the Attorney‐General time to get here. In summing up, this is a very important piece of legislation which seeks to remedy the results of the decision in Horne v. Horne in the full court of the Family Court. It is legislation which I believe is reasonable. The Attorney‐General is to be commended for introducing it to the parliament so expeditiously and—

TALK.START.PARA: —He should be chief justice!

—He would make an excellent chief justice. I have a very high respect not only for the legal capability of the Attorney‐General but also I have to say he is a great Attorney‐General. The difficulty we have in Australia is that we need him here—
—Up until now, I would commend the honourable member for Fisher for his relevance to the bill, but he has just destroyed his good record.

—I must confess that I was diverted by my friend opposite. It is important and commendable legislation. The Attorney‐General has done a great job. I urge the committee to support his efforts, to restore the situation of those people who have been disadvantaged as a result of the decision of the full court of the Family Court of Australia in the case of Horne v. Horne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) for his support of the Family Court of Western Australia (Orders of Registrars) Bill 1997 and for his embarrassing compliments that you ruled out of order. I thank honourable members on both sides of the House for their support for this remedial legislation. The bill will ensure that all people who may have been affected by the decision of the full court of the Family Court in the matter of Horne and Horne have no uncertainty about their legal status or about the legal status of what they had thought to be valid orders of the court.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill declares that all affected people have statutory family law rights and liabilities that are exercisable and enforceable in the same manner as court orders. It also provides that the same legal consequences arise out of the existence of these new statutory rights and liabilities as would have arisen out of court orders. As honourable members are aware, the speedy passage of the bill will give back legal certainty to all those people who may have been adversely affected by the matter.

A number of speakers have indicated their support for the bill but have also made additional comments in relation to matters relevant and tangentially relevant. The member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) pointed out that it is regrettable that Western Australia is the only state to take up the offer to have its own family court. This does highlight a point, which is that the Commonwealth is unable, through the lack of constitutional power, to deal with all the issues that are likely to be dealt with in the family law area, in particular in relation to de facto relationships, although there have been references of powers in relation to exnuptial children. This is a situation that does not pertain in Western Australia, where the state court exercises federal jurisdiction and also exercises state jurisdiction, and therefore can effectively cover the field.

The member for Swan (Mr Randall) also commended the unique Western Australian Family Court model, pointing out that it exercises both state and federal jurisdiction. If he is suggesting that other states ought to pick up the model and use it, I venture to suggest that that would be very difficult now, given the history of the creation of the Family Court and the separate creation of the Family Court of Western Australia.

The member for Chifley (Mr Price) has had a longstanding interest in family law matters and was the chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues in the previous parliament. I welcome his support for the proposals to re‐examine section 121 of the Family Law Act which deals with the confidentiality of proceedings. This is not the place or the time to debate that issue. He dealt also with a number of other issues, including the exercise of non‐judicial functions by the court, about which he referred to the discussion paper recently issued by my department. He referred to the effect of Brandy's case and suggested a need for a new tribunal, and he referred to a proposal that I floated some time ago with respect to the creation of a federal magistracy. I think all of those matters can be left for another day.

The child support scheme he also mentioned, that being the subject of the principal report of the committee of which he was chairman in the previous parliament. That has been the subject of announcements by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) and the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) yesterday. Again, this is not the occasion for dealing with that in any detail.

The member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) focused on the federal structure that sees a Family Court of Western Australia as well as a Family Court of Australia. Her focus of interest, however, was on the report on the front page of the Daily Telegraph yesterday referring to Australia as a `nation of bastards', which referred, of course, to the trend towards single parenthood and the trend towards de facto relationships in lieu of marriage. That simply highlights the difficulties the Commonwealth is in in relation to vesting jurisdiction over all relationship matters in the Family Court. They cannot be dealt with under the current constitutional structure.
All speakers supported the bill. It is the government's bill. The opposition supports it. It is seen to be non‐contentious and it will be beneficial. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move government amendments Nos 1 to 4:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 4, page 3 (line 28), after "court", insert "or Registrar".
(2) Clause 7, page 6 (after line 4), at the end of the clause, add:

(2) Subject to subsection (3), for the purposes of an enforcement law (see subsection (4)), any act or thing done or omitted to be done before or after the commencement of this Act gives rise to the same consequences, and is to be regarded as always having given rise to the same consequences, as if each ineffective order were an order made by the Family Court of Western Australia, in the exercise of its federal family jurisdiction, in or in relation to the proceedings for the order.

(3) If, before the commencement of this Act, a court purported to convict a person of an offence against an enforcement law on the basis that an order of the kind referred to in subsection 4(2) was a valid order, nothing in this section is to be taken to validate or confirm that conviction.
(4) In this section:

PARA.TAB: enforcement law means a provision of a law of the Commonwealth, other than a law relating to contempt of court, that sets out a consequence for a person if the person:
(a) contravenes; or
(b) acts in a specified way while there is in force;
an order, or a particular kind of order, made by a court exercising federal family jurisdiction (whether or not the provision also applies to other orders of courts).

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments proposed by the government to clause 7 will ensure that, where statutory family law rights and liabilities have been conferred by this bill, all acts or omissions will give rise to the same legal consequences as if valid court orders were in place. This includes criminal law consequences. As the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) also pointed out, the amendments will also create a minor omission in clause 4(4) of the bill. The amendments contain no significant financial impact and, given the course of the debate, are obviously not contentious. I commend the amendments to the House, and present the explanatory memorandum.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill has been agreed to with amendments. The question now is that the bill be reported to the House with amendments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funds have been allocated for overseas aid in the (a) 1993‐94, (b) 1994‐95, (c) 1995‐96, (d) 1996‐97 and (e) 1997‐98 Budgets.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to comments made by Mr L. Arnold, Chief Executive of World Vision Australia, that because of the Commonwealth's cuts to overseas aid in its 1996‐97 and 1997‐98 Budgets, the charity organisation has had to abandon the (a) Likimsi and Abella project in Ethiopia to improve the health of 41 000 people through clean water and improved sanitation, (b) Nankumba project in Malawi to provide HIV/AIDS education and home‐based care support to 62 000 people, (c) Zomba District project in Malawi to improve seed supply and increase farmer yields and food security for 30 000 people, (d) Bunyole development project in Uganda to help 10000 people affected by HIV/AIDS and (e) Maciene and Derre projects in Mozambique to improve the health of 20 000 and 37 000 people, respectively, by improving water supplies and sanitation facilities; if so, what is his response to the comments; if not, will he acquaint himself with Mr Arnold's comments and provide a response.

(3) Has he (a) received correspondence or (b) been approached by charitable organisations, including World Vision Australia, and their representatives, pointing out the consequences of the Commonwealth's cuts to its overseas aid program in its past two Budgets; if so, what (i) organisations have made official representations to him regarding the cuts and (ii) has been his response to the concerns.
(4) If he is not able to divulge which organisations have approached him, is he able to say how many have contacted him to voice their concerns; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following funds have been allocated to overseas aid: 1993‐94 $1410.80 million, 1994‐95 $1483.70 million, 1995‐96 $1567.30 million, 1996‐97 $1445.80 and 1997‐98 $1429.90 million.

(2) I am aware of the claim by the Chief Executive of World Vision Australia, Mr Lynn Arnold, that a number of the agency's projects will not proceed because of cuts to the official aid program in 1997‐98. I understand that Mr Arnold's concerns are directed in particular at the decision not to proceed with the proposed Africa NGO Program (ANGOP).

Mr Arnold's claim in respect of the World Vision projects is misleading. Total funds sought by non‐government organisations (NGOs) under ANGOP was over $34 million. This was almost four times the amount of money notionally available. In such a competitive environment there was no guarantee that any of the World Vision projects would have been funded.

Funding available for the AusAID/NGO Cooperation Program (ANCP), the central NGO funding mechanism, was increased by $3 million in the 1997/98 budget. World Vision will receive a significant proportion of these additional funds. It can allocate these funds to projects in Africa if it so chooses.
My Parliamentary Secretary, the Hon Andrew Thomson MP, and I responded to Mr Arnold's concerns, on 20 June 1997 and 22 July 1997 respectively.
Mr Arnold wrote to me on 28 July regretting the capacity for misunderstanding in the World Vision commentary on the ANGOP decision.
(3) (i) I have received correspondence and representations from charitable organisations, including World Vision with regard to cuts to the overseas aid program in the past two budgets.
1996‐97 Budget:

(a) AusAID's records indicate that 44 charitable organisations wrote to me regarding cuts to the overseas aid program. These organisations were: Amnesty International, Anglican Board of Mission, Anglican Church Office (Synod), Archbishop of Melbourne's International Relief and Development Fund, Appropriate Technology for Community and Environment (APACE), AUSTCARE, Australian Baptist World Aid Inc, Australian Catholic Relief, Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA), Australian Executive Service Overseas Program (AESOP), Australian Lutheran World Service, Australian People for Health, Education and Development Abroad (APHEDA), Canberra PLANNERS, Christian Children's Fund, Community Aid Abroad, Family Planning Tasmania, Family Planning WA, Family Planning Australia, Global Education Centre, Global Learning Centre, Institute of Sisters of Mercy, Interplast Australia, Interserve Australia, International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF), Institute of Sisters of Mercy, International Women's Development Agency, Marist Mission Centre, National Council of Churches (Australia), Overseas Service Bureau, One World Learning Centre, Parramatta Diocesan Commission for Justice and Peace, Paulian Centre, PLAN International Australia, Quaker Service (NSW), Sudan Interior Mission (SIMAID), Tasmanian Council of Churches, TEAR Australia, Save the Children, World Vision Australia, National Council of Women of Australia, the Population Council, Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, World Wide Fund for Nature (Australia), and Young Women's Christian Association (YWCA).

(b) I also had meetings with the Executive Director and Executive Committee of ACFOA, the Overseas Service Bureau and the South Australian Council of Churches during which representations were made to me regarding the 1996‐97 aid budget.
1997‐98 Budget:

(a) AusAID's records indicate that 12 charitable organisations wrote to me regarding cuts to the overseas aid program. These organisations were: Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA), Australian Expert Service Overseas Program (AESOP), African Enterprise, Australian Baptist World Service, Australian Lutheran World Service, Canberra PLANNERS, Community Aid Abroad (CAA), International Women's Development Agency, OZ Child, Quaker Service, World Vision Australia, and World Wide Fund for Nature.
(b) I met with ACFOA and World Vision during which representations were made to me regarding the 1997‐98 aid budget.

(ii) My response has been to note that Australia's aid budget, $1430 million in 1997‐98, is a very good outcome in the prevailing budgetary circumstances. Australia's Official Development Assistance (ODA) as a percentage of gross national product (GNP) is expected to be 0.27 per cent in 1997‐98, which is above the latest average for all Development Assistance Committee (DAC) donor countries (0.25 per cent in 1998). This is a considerable commitment to the reduction of poverty in developing countries.

The 1996‐97 aid budget strengthened the overriding humanitarian focus of our aid program and the 1997‐98 budget builds on those changes. Assistance to NGOs through the AusAID‐NGO Cooperation Program (ANCP) will be increased in 1997‐98 by $3 million or nearly 20 per cent. This increase to the central NGO program in a reduced aid budget is a firm indication of the Government's commitment to a genuine partnership with NGOs.

The Government indirectly supports NGOs by offering tax deductibility for financial contributions from members of the public to eligible agencies. This concession is estimated to cost up to $50 million annually in revenue forgone, and represents further recognition by the Government of the valuable role played by NGOs.
(4) According to AusAID records, all organisations that have contacted me have been noted above.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commercial Radio and Television Stations: Advertising Complaints

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What mechanisms exist for members of the public to complain about inappropriate (a) advertising material and (b) program content on commercial radio and television stations.
(2) Will the Government amend those complaints procedures; if so, what changes are being considered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Commercial radio and television services are covered by their respective industry codes of practice. For commercial television the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice (FACTS Code) (Section 6) deals with the classification and placement of commercials and is intended to ensure that television commercials are classified and broadcast appropriately, in the light of current community attitudes and of the need to limit the exposure of children to material intended for adult viewing.

The FACTS Code (Clause 7.2) provides that all written complaints about the content of television commercials (as distinct from their placement or the amount of commercials broadcast) will be referred to the Advertising Standards Council (which no longer exists) or, in the case of advertising directed to children, to the ABA.

The FACTS Code has been reviewed and the revised Code is with the ABA for registration. I understand that the revised Code refers broadcasters to any relevant industry codes of practice and therefore for taste and decency matters in advertising members of the public will be able to complain to the new Advertising Standards Board announced by the Australian Association of National Advertisers on 28 August 1997.
The Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters (FARB) Commercial Radio Code of Practice covers advertising and also includes procedures on how the stations will handle complaints.

(1) (b) Part 11 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (the Act) provides for procedures for complaints about program content on commercial radio and television programs. Complaints alleging offences against the Act and breaches of licence conditions can be made direct to the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA). Complaints concerning program content or alleging breaches of codes of practice are made to the broadcaster in the first instance. If the broadcaster does not respond within 60 days or the response is inadequate, a complaint may be made to the ABA. The ABA is required to investigate provided the complaint is in good faith and is not frivolous or vexatious. Licensees are to provide regular on air information about the code and its complaints procedures.

The FACTS Code (Clause 7.4) deals with procedures for handling oral complaints. It provides that licensees will record the substance of telephoned comments and to respond directly to callers who provide their name and contact details. Viewers who complain by telephone about material broadcast which is alleged to breach the code, and who wish to pursue the complaint further, are advised to complain in writing.

Licensees are not obliged to respond to written complaints made more than 30 days after a broadcast (Clause 7.6). If the complaint is made within the 30 days period, licensees must seek to provide a substantive response within 10 working days. Where that is not possible, the licensee will undertake in writing to provide a substantive response within a further 20 working days.

If a complainant is not satisfied with a response to a written complaint, and raises the matter further in writing to the licensee, the licensee must either reply substantively to the further letter and advise the complainant that he or she may take the complaint to the ABA.

It is the ABA's role to assess whether industry codes provide adequate safeguards, to judge the seriousness of a breach and decide on an appropriate course of action. If the ABA is satisfied that a code of practice is not operating to provide appropriate community safeguards or there is no code registered, the ABA may determine a standard (s.125 of the Act). Compliance with program standards is a condition of licence (Schedule 2).

If the ABA finds that a breach of a code of practice has occurred, this does not represent a breach of licence condition nor of the Act. Compliance with codes is not a condition of licence unless the Authority imposes such a condition.

The ABA is also required to investigate alleged breaches of licence conditions set out in subclause 7(1) of Schedule 2 and has a range of sanctions available to it including penalties from $200,000 for commercial television licensees. However it is required to use its powers in a `a manner commensurate with the seriousness of the breach' (s.5(2)). Other options available include the imposing of a condition of licence on the broadcasters requiring compliance with the code of practice. The ABA can issue notices under s.141 and failure to comply may result in penalties ranging from $2M for a commercial television licensee to $50,000 for a commercial radio licensee. Under s.143 the ABA can suspend or cancel a licence and s.125 empowers the ABA to impose a program standard that would apply to all broadcasters in the sector. In addition, the Parliament may amend standards and codes under s.128.

(2) The Government is not considering amendments to Part 11 of the Act. Changes to complaint procedures set out in industry codes of practice are a matter for the industry organisations representing the different broadcasting sectors, subject to the Act and registration by the ABA.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article appearing in the Sun Herald on 29 June 1997 at page 34 entitled "Risk to jobs highlighted".
(2) If so, do penalties exist for a company found guilty of dumping; if so what.
(3) Was a penalty sought in the case reported in the article; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Under Australia's anti‐dumping legislation, action may be taken against dumped imports only if it can be established that such dumping has caused or threatens to cause material injury to an Australian industry producing like goods. Penalties may take the form of dumping duties or, under certain circumstances, the Minister may accept a price undertaking from the exporter.

(3) In the case referred to in the article, dumping duties were sought by Faber‐Castell against highlighters dumped from Germany. In its report on this matter, the Anti‐Dumping Authority found that the goods had in fact been dumped, but that the Australian industry producing like goods (Faber‐Castell) had not suffered material injury caused by dumping and that there was not a threat of material injury from dumping of highlighters from Germany. As a result, the Authority recommended to the then Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs that no action be taken and the Minister accepted this recommendation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: How many persons are now required to refund money with respect to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) as a result of the Government's retrospective imposition of a lower threshold for the repayment of HECS.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The first point to make is that the lowering of the minimum income threshold for compulsory HECS repayment, while applying to all people with an outstanding HECS debt, is not a retrospective measure as it only applies to income earned from the 1997‐98 income year. While individuals with an outstanding HECS obligation will be required to commence repaying sooner, they will not face any increase in their outstanding HECS obligation.

The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has advised me that the number of individuals with an outstanding HECS debt who will earn an income in the 97‐98 income year which is above the minimum income threshold for compulsory HECS repayment is expected to rise by an estimated 156,722 to 409,038 as a result of the lowering of the minimum income threshold to $20,701.

However, individuals with an outstanding HECS debt who have a spouse or dependent children, and who would otherwise be required to make repayments as a result of the lowering of the repayment threshold, will be exempt from making repayments if they receive an exemption or reduction of the Medicare levy because of low family income. This has the potential to benefit more than 14,000 people with an outstanding HECS obligation who would otherwise be expected to make a repayment in 1997‐98.
